{{Template:Pictures}}
'''[[Veganwiki]]''' is a wiki about anything related to [[veganism]]. So far we have '''{{NUMBEROFARTICLES}} articles'''. It was started in 2013 by [[User:Guaka|Guaka]], and is continued by a bunch of enthusiasts, including perhaps you! This wiki is definitely not limited to vegan editors. In most places and cultures it's hard to be vegan. We want to encourage anyone to at least try a vegan lifestyle for a while or for some days of the week ([[Meatless Monday]] for example?). So folks who eat meat or dairy are still very welcome to participate. We have some basic [[Project:guidelines|guidelines]]. We'll also allow some [[vegetarianism|vegetarian]] stuff - as for example a vegetarian restaurant in [[Brussels]] is already way better than 99% of the places that cater food. But there is no space for recipes with cow [[milk]] or [[eggs]]. Click a red link to start writing! Or click blue ones and edit them! Or just create a new page! Don't know how? Ask us via our [[Community portal]]! == News == * February 28th, 2013 - Our first spammer. We'll probably enforce sign ups this week. * February 20th, 2013 - We have a preliminary [[logo]] thanks to [[User:Mikael|Mikael]]! * February 18th, 2013 - '''vegan.wiki.yt''' was launched! == Topics == [[Why become vegan]] | [[How to become vegan]] | [[How to stay vegan]] | [[Travel guide]] | [[Raw veganism]] | [[History of veganism]] | [[Vegan Meli-Melo]] | [[Testimonials]] === [[Food]] === [[Milk]], [[chocolate]], [[quinoa]], [[soy]], [[tofu]], [[tempeh]] [[honey]], [[cheese]], [[eggs]], [[fish sauce]], [[sugar]] === [[Recipes]] === [[vegan pancakes]], [[cranberry orange sweet bread]], [[falafel]] [[vegan chocolate cake]], [[aubergines farcies]], [[pâtes au chou-fleur grillé]], [[aubergines]], [[cakes]], [[cauliflower]], [[ice cream]], [[Indian recipes]], [[milk]], [[pancakes]], [[pâte brisée]], [[pizza]], [[pumpkins]], [[quiches]] === [[Health]] === [[B12]], [[Calcium]], [[Vitamin D]] === [[Animal rights]] === [[Animal testing]], [[meat industry]], [[pigs]], [[rabbits]], [[cows]], [[horses]], [[bees]] === [[Environment]] === [[Climate change]], [[Deforestation and biodiversity loss]], [[Water pollution]], [[Water scarcity]]...
{{World}}
== Sister projects == Many of the folks here are also active on [[:trash:|Trashwiki]], [[:hitch:|Hitchwiki]] and [[:bw:|BeWelcome]] __NOTOC__ [[Category:Browse]]

Wikimaniac!
I am not 100% vegan but I would be if it were easy enough.
I started [[:hitch:|Hitchwiki]], [[:trash:|Trashwiki]], [[:couch:|Couchwiki]] and some more wikis.
In 2013 I registered [http://wiki.yt/ <tt>wiki.yt</tt>] so that I can have nice domain names for wikis without paying to much to registrars. What do YouThink?

'''Brussels''' is much less vegan friendly than one would expect of the capital [[Belgium]] and [[Category:Europe|Europe]] but there are still some nice places to discover.
== Vegan restaurants == There is only one vegan restaurant: * Den Teepot, Rue des Chartreux 66, Brussels. It's usually open for lunch and organic macro-biotic food is served.
== Vegetarian restaurants == * There's an Egyptian [[falafel]] place at Anspach. Probably the tastiest falafel in town. And no meat is served here. * Dolma, Chaussee d'Ixelles. Vegetarian buffet in the evening.
[[Category:Belgium]]

'''Belgium''' is a weird country in [[Category:Europe|Europe]]. Flanders, the Dutch speaking part in the North, is by far more vegan friendly than Wallonia.
Belgian cuisine is not very friendly to vegetarians, let alone to vegans. In most restaurants you'll have a hard time finding a vegan option, Asian restaurants being the usual exception (but watch out for [[fish sauce]]).
== Supermarket food == In most supermarkets you can find [[milk|rice milk]]. Unfortunately, like in the [[Netherlands]], most fake meat is not vegan. They put [[eggs]] and sometimes [[dairy]] in it. [[Soy]] is fairly common, also organic soy.
If you're into [[chocolate]] you should check out the Cote d'Or pure chocolate spread. It's vegan and pretty awesome.
{{Template:Belgium}}
<small>[[trash:Belgium|Trashwiki]] / [[hitch:Belgium|Hitchwiki]]</small> [[Category:Belgium]] [[Category:Europe]]

How to replace '''eggs''' in [[vegan recipes]]?
Depends why you are using the eggs, or wich part is really important in the recipe you are preparing :
Yellow part, more fat, may be replaced with a bit water or oil.
White part is a kind of glue, wich can be replaced by a half smashed banana, a bit of smashed steam cooked potato, a spoon tapioca or flower, rolled [[Oat]] ...
{{stub}}
[[Category:Food]]

{{stub}} When one says '''milk''' most people directly think of a cow milk. Fortunately for vegans (and lactose-intolerant folks) there are tons of other types of milk such as soy milk, rice milk, hemp milk, oat milk, almond milk, etc. Some of them are excellent to use for direct drinking, others suit best for replacing cow milk and cream while cooking. Those milks are usually availlable in most of grocery stores (in developed countries) as well as in organic&vegetarian shops.
You can also make these milks yourself. Usually you just need to soak ingredients in fresh water overnight, then cook them, put through a powerfull blender, and then filter out hard leftovers. The dry residue can be used for other recipes.
==Soy milk== [[File:Soy_milk.jpg|left|thumb|240px|Soy milk]] Soy milk is a good and probably most commons replacement for dairy milk. It's quite thick. Most soy milks (at least in Europe) are GMO free, but watch out for genetically modified soy nonetheless, since it is one of the most GM ingredients in the world (the big part of GM soy serves as a feed for livestock, though).
Beware that some people are allergic to soy milk.
==Rice milk== [[File:Lima-organic-lactosefree-vegan-ricemilk-from-Germany-1liter-bottle+cup-1024px.jpg|thumb|right|240px|''Lima'' organic rice milk]] Rice milk is a grain milk made from [[rice]]. It's usually not sweetened, the sweet taste comes from a natural enzymatic process.
== Links == * http://www.cfaitmaison.com/bio/faire-laits.html (French)
[[Category:Food]]

page.title: Veganwiki:How we want to keep Veganwiki

revision.text:
We're writing '''Veganwiki''' from a vegan point of view.
==Guidelines / Ideas / Concepts we like here ==
''Rule #1: we try to avoid setting up rules''
===Spirit of cooperation=== * Most action ''just happens'' - someone has an idea, goes ahead and does it. * In case there's doubt if all veganwiki editors would be happy with an action: we want a democratic work environment, where we first try to decide by consensus. * We encourage active member participation and try to keep convivial work environments ** Try to stay friendly, e.g. not "your stuff sucks so I deleted it", but "maybe you could try to do it like this or that the next time?".
===Transparency=== * As much communication and information as possible is and will be available on the internet. This excludes information such as server passwords, but it goes as far as what [[Special:Version|software and extensions]] are running on Veganwiki, and naturally a [[Special:Recentchanges|history of all edits ever made]]. * Many decisions are made and discussed in wikipages.
===Free software=== * We exclusively use [http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_software free software]. The entire server stack, MediaWiki, any mailing list software, everything is and should be free.
===Open data=== * We want to keep [[project:database dumps|database dumps]] available at all times. * We want to support open formats and standards, such as OpenID and microformats.
===Free license=== * Content is licensed under the Creative Commons ShareAlike Attribution license.
===International=== * Given enough interest, people should be allowed to set up their own language version.
===Not for profit=== * Veganwiki costs us almost nothing, so we don't need money to run it and it's unlikely we would need money in the future. * Veganwiki is officially owned by [[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) but if it reaches a critical mass it makes sense to transfer ownership to an official organisation.
not sure yet: * We don't want advertising or affiliate marketing. We would only accept it in case money would be needed and other forms of fund-raising are not succeeding.

'''Veganwiki''' is a collaborative project to gather information useful for vegans and wannavegans (such as e.g. vegetarians).
It was started in 2013 by [[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) and some friends.
[[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) felt the need for a wiki resource related to veganism. It does not want to compete with existing vegan and vegetarian websites.
[[Category:Veganwiki]]

{{stub}} Despite the ubiquity of [[vegan cheese|cheese]] the '''Netherlands''' has a growing [[veganism|vegan]] cuisine.
== Supermarket food == [[Peanut butter]] everywhere, and cheap! Fake meat such as ''[[Quorn]]'' is not vegan as it contains [[eggs]] and sometimes [[dairy]]. In many places you can also find some good [[Indonesia]]n stuff like [[sambal]] and [[tempeh]]. ''[[Albert Heijn]]'''s pure chocolate spread is vegan but it's quite tasteless compared to the ''Cote d'Or'' spread you can get in [[Belgium]].
{{Template:Netherlands}}
[[Category:Netherlands]] [[Category:Europe]]

'''Vegan pancakes''' are super easy to make. You just make pancakes and don't put any dairy milk or eggs. [[Milk|Soy milk]] is a great replacement.
[[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) usually just adds stuff randomly: first flour, then soy milk, possibly some [[no egg]], stir, some salt, some random ingredients (black pepper, ginger), mix it properly, heat up some oil, and make pancakes. Please add your more detailed recipes here!
{{stub}}

'''München''' is Bavaria's capital in [[Germany]] and has a few explicitly [[vegan]] places, even if in general the city doesn't seem to be so vegan-friendly. The local Bavarian cuisine is actually exactly the opposite.
== Eating out == The extremely high rent all over the city, and the loss of more alternative culture to populate such locations, makes it really hard to keep a restaurant up, so often it's just a matter of time before it has to shut down - like the fantastic ''Kopfeck'', the ''Kaede'', the ''Zerwirk'', or ''Fräulein Müller Brotzeitladen'', all gone by now.
Vegan and vegetarian restaurants which still operate:
* ''[http://www.max-pett.de/blog/ Max Pett]'' at the Sendlinger Tor, very central. It has a completely vegan menu. Monday to Saturday open 10.00 to 23.00, it's in Pettenkoferstraße 8, 80336 München.
* ''[http://tushita.eu/essen Tushita Teehaus]'', with a wide selection of great teas, all of them organic. There is always at least two dishes, one dish of the day and one sandwich, different every day (sometimes even pizza). A lot of cakes, also smoothies. Everything is vegan. It's in Klenzestr. 53, D-80469 München, open Mo-Fr from 09:00 to 20:00 and Saturday 10:00 to 20:00.
* ''[http://www.princess-chocolate.com Princess SchokoBar]'': awesomely homemade pralines, cupcakes, tartes... huge variety! Also workshops to learn how to make all that foodstuff yourself. The whole shop is vegan, lactose-free, organic and fairtrade. Address: Haimhauserstr. 3a, 80802 München.
* ''Pavesi Picnic'', in Schwabing, friendly people, all vegan, local ingredients for the big part, menu depends on a season, really good Indian food like Masala Dosa.
* ''[http://www.ignaz-cafe.de/cms/ Cafe Ignáz]'' in Schwabing, also lists vegetarian dishes on its menu, but has a wide variety of good vegan cakes, cookies, conditory, and various second dishes. Cafés owner has a very family-like way to treat his customers. All in all it is a cute, small cafe with a nice location. There is a happy hour on Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday from 15:00 to 18:00, all main dishes for 6,90 Euro.
* ''[http://royal-veggie-doener.eu/royal/ Royal Veggie Doener]'' at the central station has a vegan kebab.
* ''Ballabeni'' next to the Pinakothek der Moderne is a popular place and therefore it is always crowded there, one has to wait up to 15 mins till one can order. But the ice cream is excellent, vegan and self-made.
* There are more restaurants like ''[http://www.charl.ie/ Charlie]'' with Vietnamese cuisine, and ''[http://www.roecklplatz.de/ Roecklplatz]'' where they aim to support "socially disadvantaged" teens through training and work - these places are not vegetarian or vegan at all, but have some OK selection of vegan food nonetheless. ''[http://www.sababa-munich.com/index.html Sababa]'' has good falafel.
== Shopping == Among vegetarian and organic supermarkets there is one only-vegan supermarket called ''[http://www.radixversand.de/ Radix]'', which has also an online-shop.
== Voküs == There are two vegan Voküs (= Volksküchen, "public kitchen", i.e. there is free food on a regular basis) in München.
* Every Wednesday and Friday at ''[http://kafemarat.blogsport.de/Kafe Marat]''. * Every second Thursday of the month at the trailer park ''[http://olga089.blogsport.de/ Stattpark Olga]'', drinks on donation, often accompanied by a free concert or event.
== Dumpster diving == Much of vegetables and fruits in this city can be acquired by practice of dumpter diving. See [http://trashwiki.org/en/Munich Trashwiki] for more info.
== Other resources == * The ''Kafe Marat'' has also a collection of vegan recipes on its website, in German: http://kafemarat.blogsport.de/volxkuechen-kochbuch * http://www.veggie-love.de/2011/05/food-love-muenchen - German article on vegetarian and vegan restaurants in Munich
{{Template:Germany}} [[Category:Germany]]

{{veganwiki}} We do not just want to have Veganwiki in English. If there's enough interest we can set up specific wikis in other languages as well. For now, it's okay if you write here in other languages, we'll just mark them as such.
There's already a [http://de.veganwiki.org/ German language at de.veganwiki.org]. If you want to write in German this could be a good place. Or not, please report back. There's no clear content license unfortunately.

Vegan for a few month now after being vegetarian flexitarian for several years.
First was a kind of experiment for my roomy and me ... then ... illumination ...
Even if animals, environment and health are importants, I think I went in this direction mostly because it fits with my global ethic of life, a curious mix of pleasure and anticonsumerism
Adept of DIY about basic foods, was doing my own cheese, stoped but keep on doing natural yeast bread, lactofermentations, probiotic drinks and food, liqors, etc
Curiously my familly accepted it more than vegetarianism : my father was worrying, asked his doctor to know if it was not dangerous for my health, the doctor answered he is himself vegan for 30 years !
Yet I am still eating a bit honey when I a sick,
I accept sometimes some human proteins too ... ohhh you'r looking appetizing you know ?
Hope to create or join a (vegan?)commune one day and to reach an acceptable level of sustainability (economic social environment human cultural) before the world colapses

[[File:Kombucha.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Kombucha]] '''Vitamin B12''' is a very important vitamin for our nervous system. Even if requirements are very low, missing it may have important and long term bad consequences. But more than for other vitamins, the question of the replacement of animal B12 is complex, and got sometimes several contradictory answers. For some people (even [[veganism|vegans]]) we cannot find this B12 in non animal products, and we should replace it with some B12 tablets. For others, B12 deficiency as consequence of veganism is a myth, as some bacterias are producing B12 directly in our digestive system. A median solution, at same time natural, vegan, and gastronomicaly awesome could be to use nutritional [[yeast]], and drink sometimes a glass of [[Kombucha]] (Combucha Comboucha), the 2000 years old traditional fermentated [[tea]], which contains B12 and other important life components.
[[Category:Health]]

[[File:BUTTON vegan star2.0.JPG|right]] '''Veganism''' is a philosophy and practice of abstaining from the use of animal products, particularly in diet. That is, vegans choose not to eat food that comes from animals, including meat, eggs and dairy products (like [[milk]], cheese, and yogurt). A vegan diet is sometimes called a strict [[vegetarian]] diet. Vegans try not to use any other animal products, such as leather, wool, feathers, bone, or pearl. They also try to avoid products that have been tested on animals. Many vegans believe in [[animal rights]], and may campaign for it. Vegans do eat all kinds of fruits, vegetables, beans, grains, nuts, and seeds, and things made from them like vegan sweets, vegan cheese and vegan cakes.
Reasons to become vegan are [[ethics|ethical]], [[health]], [[religion|religious]], [[environment]]al, socio-economical, etc.
===Related Veganwiki pages=== * [[Why become vegan]] * [[History of veganism]]

[[Category:France]] [[Category:Europe]]

As in other average [[France|French]] cities, vegan places are quite rare in [[Strasbourg]]. We can at least find some shops or restaurants wich are, if not vegan, at least vegetarian or vegan friendly.
== Groceries ==
Organic stores, even if distributing meat, eggs and dairy products, are nice places to find specific and sometimes rare vegan groceries : * Biocoop * Serpent Vert * Vivre BIO "La Maison Vitale"
Markets are nice places to find vegetables : * Neudorf, Place du Marché * Boulevard de la Marne * Producteurs (place du Marché aux Poissons, currently moved rue de la Douane) : the greatest one, with only organic, local and season products, sometimes rare vegetables, as old traditional apple species, savage garlic, special pumkins, ... unfortunately not the cheapest
AMAPS: Amaps are consumers cooperatives wich are buying directly to some choosen farmers.
== Restaurants == Some restaurant are at least vegan friendly : * La Robe des Champs * Le Potiron
== NGOs == [[File:Food-not-bombs-affiche-211x300.jpg|right|thumb|240px|Poster for ''Food Not Bombs'' gatherings]] * Animal Protection and promotion of vegetarianism; Animalsace. See link below. * The ''[[Food not Bombs]]'' collective is normaly organizing a free vegan food once a month (the second wednesday), rue du Faubourg National.
== Links == * http://www.strasbourg.com/strasbourg/fr/gourmet/marches/120.html (Strasbourg Markets, days and places) * http://www.animalsace.org/ (French) * http://veganstrasbourg.noblogs.org/
{{Template:France}}
[[Category:France]]

{{stub}} There is a number of reasons why people become [[veganism|vegans]]. It could be an ethical choice (caring for animal rights), or for health reasons, or because of ones religious beliefs, or simply out of environmental or socio-economical concerns. But the reasons are not limited to those said above: some folks become vegans more out of curiosity, protest against society and the system, or just because it feels good.
=== Animal rights === ...
=== Health === ...
=== Environment === ...
===Religious beliefs=== ...
===Socio-economical concerns=== ...
[[Category:General info]]

'''Sugar''' might be less [[veganism|vegan]] than you think.
Some char derived from [[cow]] [[bones]] is often used as a filter to whiten sugar during the refining process.
Unfortunaly the sugar packagings do not mention the process used.
Knowing the brands does not help as several manufactures are often working following different processes, for the same brand.
Using brown sugar is not a solution, brown sugar is often refined, and made brown again.
We can find alternatives in special organic groceries, selling vegan sugar not using this refining process.
== Links == * http://www.vrg.org/journal/vj2007issue4/2007_issue4_sugar.php
[[Category:Food]]

[[File:Ha-iu.JPG|right|200px]] In South East [[Category:Asia|Asia]] and Southeast Asian restaurants it's very common to add '''fish sauce''' to about any dish you can get in front of you.
If you want to keep a strict vegetarian [[fish]] free diet you'll have to enquire about this before ordering food.
[[Category:Food]]
[[Category:France]]

'''Food not Bombs''' is a name of collectives organised across the globe. It started in the [[United States]] but it's also happening in [[Strasbourg]] for example.
{{stub}}

[[File:Falafel balls.jpg|right|300px]] '''Israel''' is a great country for [[veganism|vegans]]. There are tons of [[falafel]] and [[humus]] places.
== Kosher laws == Kosher laws are mostly great for vegans. The ''kashrut'' also makes sure that meat and dairy products are never mixed. So if you go to a Jewish "meaty" restaurant you won't get any dairy in your food. Kosher laws still allow mixing [[eggs]] and [[honey]] into other foods but when something is ''parve'', also noted on many products (check for a פַּרוֶוה label).
== Cities and towns == * [[Tel Aviv]] * [[Jerusalem]] * <small>''add more?''</small>
[[Category:Israel]] [[Category:Asia]]

{{stub}} '''Tel Aviv''' is a cool [[Israel]]i city.
== Restaurants == * ''[http://www.buddhaburgers.co.il/english.asp Buddha Burgers]'' is purely vegan and has some great stuff on the menu. Definitely check out the salad bar and the desserts.
[[Category:Israel]]

[[File:Animal_rights_graffiti_in_Vilnius_2009_III.JPG|thumb|300px|right|[[Animal rights]] graffiti in Vilnius. It says: "We are cared after worse than the worst criminals. And eventually killed." Note the parody on UN logotype: UN in Lithuanian is JTO, but they wrote JGO, which can be understood as United Animals Organization.]] '''Vilnius''' is the capital of [[Lithuania]]. It is fairly easy to be a vegan here: even though many still won't know what [[veganism]] is, you have a variety of vegan-friendly shops and cafés to choose from. Besides, you will have no problem finding plenty of various fruit&veg in ordinary grocery stores.
== Eating out == Vegetarian/vegan: * ''[http://www.baltidrambliai.lt Balti drambliai]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Vilniaus+g.41&sll=54.694933,25.253265&sspn=0.020214,0.055747&g=7+Latvi%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97,+%C5%BDv%C4%97rynas,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+apskritis+08001,+LIthuania&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=41+Vilniaus+gatv%C4%97,+Senamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01013,+Lithuania&ll=54.681678,25.28055&spn=0.002528,0.006968&t=h&z=18 Vilniaus 41]. Probably most popular vegetarian place in Vilnius. Indian style cuisine. Vegan options marked separately (but double check for [[honey]]!). * ''[http://www.radharane.lt/ Radharanė]'', addresses: [http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=sv&geocode=&q=gedimino+pr.32+vilnius&aq=&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=36.178967,86.572266&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=32+Gedimino+prospektas,+Naujamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01013,+Litauen&z=16 Gedimino 32] and [http://www.ozas.lt/kaip-mus-rasti Ozo 18] (''Ozo prekybos centras'' shopping mall, 3 floor). Vegetarian, Indian style cuisine. Ask for vegan options, without [[ghee]]. * ''[http://www.facebook.com/Raw42 Raw42]'' , address: [http://maps.google.se/maps?q=+R%C5%ABdnink%C5%B3+12+vilnius&hl=sv&ie=UTF8&sll=54.686161,25.282265&sspn=0.006735,0.021136&t=h&hnear=R%C5%ABdnink%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+12,+Senamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01135,+Litauen&z=16 Rūdninkų 12]. Vegan raw food, cocktails, raw pizzas and desserts. * ''[http://www.shivabar.lt/ Shiva Chill Bar]'', address: [http://www.bing.com/maps/default.aspx?v=2&pc=FACEBK&mid=8100&rtp=adr.~pos.54.6818695_25.2783604_SHIVABAR_Klaip%C4%97dos+g.+3%2C+Vilnius%2C+Lithuania&cp=54.6818695~25.2783604&lvl=16&sty=r&rtop=0~0~0~&mode=D&FORM=FBKPL1&mkt=en-US Klaipėdos 3]. Vegetarian. * ''[http://sulcius.lt/ Sulčius]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Totori%C5%B3+15+Vilnius&sll=54.686485,25.282245&sspn=0.011287,0.027595&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=15+Totori%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97,+Vilnius,+Vilnius+Region+01013,+Lithuania&ll=54.6845,25.282288&spn=0.011288,0.027595&z=15 Totorių 15]. A small vegetarian place, mostly for raw cocktails. * ''[http://www.facebook.com/sv.vieta Šv.Vieta]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=12+%C5%A0v.+Ignoto+gatv%C4%97,+Vilnius,+Lithuania&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.681597,25.284476&spn=0.013472,0.042272&sll=59.326142,17.982052&sspn=0.190208,0.676346&oq=%C5%A0v.+Ignoto+12&hnear=%C5%A0v.+Ignoto+gatv%C4%97+12,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+miesto+savivaldyb%C4%97+01144,+Lithuania&t=m&z=15 Šv.Ignoto 12 – 1]. Vegetarian. * ''[http://www.kavinetavoerdve.lt/ Tavo erdvė]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=26+%C5%A0eimyni%C5%A1ki%C5%B3+g.,+Vilnius,+Lithuania&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.694769,25.287609&spn=0.026935,0.084543&sll=54.681597,25.284476&sspn=0.013472,0.042272&oq=%C5%A0eimyni%C5%A1ki%C5%B3+g.+26,+Vilnius,+Lithuania&hnear=%C5%A0eimyni%C5%A1ki%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+26,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+miesto+savivaldyb%C4%97+09322,+Lithuania&t=m&z=14 Šeimyniškių 26]. Vegetarian. * ''Vegafé'' ([http://www.jogosmityba.lt/vegafe 1],[http://www.jogosmityba.lt/index.php?id=869 2]), adresses: [http://maps.google.se/maps?q=Totori%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+3,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis,+Lietuva&hl=sv&ie=UTF8&sll=54.67914,25.289764&sspn=0.006736,0.021136&t=h&hnear=Totori%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+3,+Senamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01121,+Litauen&z=16 Totorių 3] and [http://maps.google.se/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=sv&geocode=&q=Augustijon%C5%B3++2+Vilnius&aq=&sll=61.606396,21.225586&sspn=22.038019,86.572266&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=2+Augustijon%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97,+Senamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01013,+Litauen&t=h&z=16 Augustijonų 2]. Vegetarian ayurvedic food at yoga center. Offers daily specials with one vegan special available marked. Other vegan options are available and marked. Wide range of juices and smoothies. A large portion of the menu items are Asian inspired (Indian and Chinese). An English menu is available. The restaurant will pack your order for take-away. * ''[http://www.rawraw.lt/ RawRaw]'', address: [http://maps.google.se/maps?q=Totori%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+3,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis,+Lietuva&hl=sv&ie=UTF8&sll=54.67914,25.289764&sspn=0.006736,0.021136&t=h&hnear=Totori%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+3,+Senamiestis,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+Apskritis+01121,+Litauen&z=16 Totorių 3]. Raw food restaurant. Nearly everything is vegan. Foods containing honey are clearly marked. * ''[http://www.zaliasisbambukas.lt Žaliasis bambukas]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Latvi%C5%B3+7a+Vilnius&sll=54.681467,25.284644&sspn=0.011289,0.027595&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=7+Latvi%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97,+%C5%BDv%C4%97rynas,+Vilnius,+Vilniaus+apskritis+08001,+LIthuania&z=15 Latvių 7A]. Vegetarian. * <small>[http://vegan.wiki.yt/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=submit add a new place?]</small>
Veg-friendly: * ''[http://www.manoguru.lt/ Mano guru]'', address: Vilniaus 22/1. Salad bar with vegan and vegetarian options. Juices and desserts also available. Price: Moderate. * ''Sue's Indian Raja''. address: Odminių 3. Indian cuisine, vegan meals available on a request.
== Vegan-friendly shops == * ''Sveiki Produktai'' around the city and [http://www.sveikiproduktai.lt/ webshop] * ''Sanga'' [http://sanga.lt/ webshop] * <small>[http://vegan.wiki.yt/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=submit add a new place?]</small>

Staying [[veganism|vegan]] while traveling is not super easy. Well, some people claim it is but others have a harder time finding proper food. On [[Veganwiki]] we want to create an up-to-date guide of places that you want to go to. We'll also point you to Trashwiki at times when cities have good trash to offer.

Staying healthy on a vegan diet is easier than you think. Normally you'll already eat way more fruit and veggies than average. Proteins are definitely not a problem, unlike the ideas of many meat eaters. Things to watch for: [[B12]], [[vitamin D]], [[calcium]].

[[Veganism|Vegans]] seem sometimes obsessed with '''food'''. It remains for all of us the common issue regardless our motivations for veganism.
What do vegans eat? What sould vegans avoid? Why? How to replace a non-vegan ingredient with a vegan one? This is a space for the answers to such questions.

[[Category:Food]]

Most of time '''soy sprouts''' are not made out of soybeans, but of [[mung beans]].
There is currently a lot of discussions about soy and soy sprouts containing some natural toxines : [[Soy|Soy, myth and reality]].
[[Category:Food]]

{{stub}} '''Soy''' is a very common food for [[veganism|vegans]].
==Myth and reality == ''Serious contribution needed.''
The issue of eventual toxins in soy is so controversial, that the contributor does not feel currently authorized or competent to take part for one or the other thesis.
Soy is certainly neither a miracle food nor something to banish, but should be used without excess in a varied diet.
Soy milk is just one of the several existing non dairy [[milk]]s, and there is plenty of other sources of plant-based [[protein]]s.
[[Category:Food]]

'''Fermentation''' is a traditional process to keep some vegetables eatable for many month, sometimes years. The natural fermentation will produce some CO2 and lactic acids wich will protect the vegetables from other unwanted bacterias. This process is famous for cabbage (choucroute-sauerkraut), pickles (cornichons, concombres), green beans (Local tradition, Alsace, France) but results are great with carots, celeriac, keleks and many other vegetables.
Preparation is simple but requires a lot of attention and hygiene, to avoid the development of undesirable and pathogens bacterias. As the vegetables are not boiled, nutrients are preserved and even enhanced by the fermentation. [[Soy sauce]], [[tempeh]] and [[miso]] are produced with soy fermentation.
== Links == * http://fr.ekopedia.org/Lacto-fermentation (French) * http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauerkraut
[[Category:Food]]

We must be honest, being vegan is not easy, and sometimes it looks as a perpetual quest.
We can avoid meat, eggs, dairy products, and later, understand how [[sugar]] is produced, notice our favorite sweet thai basil pesto contains some eggs, or learn some E... food additiv is animal derived!
The social pressure is important, our friends don't understand why we don't join them anymore to some restaurant, our familly is worrying about our [[nutritional deficiencies]], our doctor explains we NEED to eat meat because we got some canines.
Sometimes we are lazy and would just like to buy a frozen [[pizza]] and heat it in the microwave.
But with time, we'll get used to read food labels with a lot of attention, cook better than the chef of the restaurant, teach to our familly we don't have sugar or cholesterol problems, and, if we are courageous, show to our doctor a picture of a lion, to teach him what real canines are looking like.
And lets say it, a microwave heaten pizza is really something disgusting.
So how to stay vegan?
As for a lot of thing, the main path will be the pleasure!
Discovering each day new taste, new vegetables, new fruits, with a bit experience, we'll even save time, cooking stuffed [[eggplants]] one day, and using the same filling in the following days for preparing another meal, discovering richess of cereals we'll even forget potatoes are existing!
With time we'll feel lighter, cleaner, better in our body, not smeared anymore, maybe lose weight, .
And we wish that with this Vegan Wiki you will not feel alone anymore.
Keep following your way!
[[Category:General info]]

'''Cereals''' are the grains of some plants of the botanic graminéas familly:
* [[Wheat]] : [[Common wheat]] (French : Froment, Blé tendre), [[Durum]] (French : Blé dur) * [[Splet]] (French : Grand épeautre, engrain) * [[Einkorn wheat]], (French : Petit épeutre) * [[Corn]] (French: Maïs) * [[Rice]](French: Riz) * [[Barley]] (French: Orge) * [[Oat]] (French: Avoine) * [[Millet]] (French: Millet, Petit mil) * [[Sorgo]] (French: Sorgho, Grand mil) * [[Rye]] (French: Seigle)
Some other grains are often called céreals or '''pseudo cereals''' even if they don't belong to this plant familly : * [[Buckwheat]] (French : Sarrazin) : [[Kasha]] (Grilled Buckwheat) * [[Quinoa]]
[[Category:Food]]

[[File:Havregryn2.JPG|thumb|240px|right|Oatmeal]] '''Oat''', or more precisely '''oatmeal''' ('''oat flakes'''), may be used to replace [[eggs|egg white]] in some recipes: just mix oats with water, and this mixture will help to glue together burgers, etc.
[[Category:Food]]

'''Honey''' is not very [[veganism|vegan]]. Still quite a few folks calling themselves vegan eat honey and don't care too much about [[bees]].
Fortunately there are also fairly good alternatives to honey, such as agave and maple syrup.
[[Category:Non-vegan food]]
[[Category:Food]]

[[File:2007 GGT info-table.jpg|thumb|300px|Vegan activism in Lithuania (members of ''Animal Rights Lithuania'' having a street stall in [[Kaunas]].)]] '''Lithuania''' is a Baltic country in [[Category:Europe|Europe]]. Even though Lithuanians generally live on a meat-based diet, there is a growing [[veganism|vegan]] and raw food movement, and you can certainly get around being a vegan in this small country, even though some difficulties (in communicating your needs) may occur.
== Activism == * ''Animal Rights Lithuania'' is an organization with focus on [[animal rights]]. It is the only organization of its kind in the country, with activists from all around Lithuania. Vegan education and abolitionism are primary strategies and goals of most of the active members of this group. Website: [http://animalrights.lt/en animalrights.lt] | Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/groups/gerbkgyvunuteises
== Links == * If you want to meet other vegetarian or vegan families in Lithuania, there is a Facebook group for that: http://www.facebook.com/groups/veg.seimos * Following Facebook group unites random Lithuanian vegetarians and vegans: http://www.facebook.com/groups/108891465822030 * [http://gyventisamoningai.lt ''Gyventisamoningai.lt''] (''Living Consciously'') is a green Lithuanian blog with veganism as one of its baselines. Topics on environmental activism and human and animal rights make it even more diverse. * [http://kavalgoveganai.blogspot.se Ką valgo veganai?] - vegan recipies for Lithuanians.
{{Template:Lithuania}}
[[Category:Lithuania]] [[Category:Europe]]

'''India''' is a great place for vegetarians. For vegans things are not so easy as a lot of food is prepared with dairy such as [[ghee]]. In general it helps to state that you're "pure veg", which already means vegetarian and no eggs. If you want to avoid dairy you'll have to state this and be very clear about it, and possibly repeat your statement 4 times or so (as things go in India).
== Cities == * [[Mumbai]] * [[Kolkota]]
[[Category:Asia]]

page.title: Veganwiki talk:How we want to keep Veganwiki

revision.text: I'm not sure about the "no advertising" and "no affiliate" part, which is extremely clear with e.g. Trashwiki and quite clear for Hitchwiki. I would never want to see any annoying ads here or on a mobile version of this project but I'm not sure if less intrusive advertising is necessarily bad. Of course there should be some restrictions to the advertising, such as only animal friendly products and companies. And the money should go towards improving the project, which should happen in the most transparent way possible. For example, if it grows big enough with enough visitors I can see Veganwiki sponsorships by companies that sell vegan food (only) or vegan fake leather shoes and the money can be used for organising something like a Vegan Wiki hackathon or unconference. Anyway, I want this to be a collective project just like the other cool wikis. So... What do you think? [[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) 23:36, 21 February 2013 (CET) : I think that advertising can be possible and useful in the future, if 1. it is vegan-friendly; 2. it is limited to some extent, i.e. if you look on the screen the advertising should not take larger area than let's say 3-5%. Or smth like that. :) --[[User:Sigurdas|Sigurdas]] ([[User talk:Sigurdas|talk]]) 23:51, 21 February 2013 (CET)

Hi Sigurdas! Great to see your edits here, I'm excited about this project! I'm curious what you think about [[Veganwiki talk:How we want to keep Veganwiki|how we want to keep this wiki]].
Oh, and there was also a request to set up busk.wiki.yt. Would you be interested? I wouldn't be editing there myself very much so I want there at least to be one experienced wiki dude looking at recent changes regularly before I set it up. [[User:Guaka|Guaka]] ([[User talk:Guaka|talk]]) 23:51, 21 February 2013 (CET) : Kasper, quality not quantity, or what do you think? The reason I've abandoned editing on Hitchwiki is because I saw Trashwiki as a priority, and I do not have time for more wikis in my life (I wish I had!). Now I guess I will be balancing between Trashwiki and Veganwiki, and unfortunately I barely see a busking wiki as a priority over the other ones. So I guess I say NO this time. --[[User:Sigurdas|Sigurdas]] ([[User talk:Sigurdas|talk]]) 23:57, 21 February 2013 (CET)

[[File:Painted Pony Bean.JPG|thumb|240px|right|"Painted Pony" dry bean (Phaseolus vulgaris)]] '''Beans''' are great for [[veganism|vegans]] as they are full of proteins.
== Types of Beans == * [[Mung beans|Mung Bean]] * <small>''add more?''</small>
==Nutrition facts== Beans have significant amounts of fiber and soluble fiber, with one cup of cooked beans providing between nine and 13 grams of fiber. Soluble fiber can help lower blood cholesterol. Beans are also high in protein, complex carbohydrates, folate, and iron.

[[File:Sa green gram.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Mung beaans]] '''Mung beans''' are [[beans]], commonly used in [[China|Chinese]] cuisine.
One can easily sprout mung beans at home. Its sprouts are germinated by leaving them in water for 4 hours of daytime light and spending the rest of the day in the dark. Mung bean sprouts can be grown under artificial light for 4 hours over the period of a week.
== Recipes == * [http://www.yummly.com/recipe/external/Savory-mung-bean-crepes-324385 Savory Mung Bean Crepes]
[[Category:Food]]

J'adore cette recette ! Dire que je n'aimais pas le [[cauliflower|chou-fleur]] avant d'etre végan. C'est très simple, à part le choufleur vous avez forcément tout dans votre cuisine :
Vous séparez les têtes, les humectez avec un peu d'[[huile d'olive]] et placez cela sur une plaque ou même la lechefrite tout en haut du four en position grill. Vous les laissez bien griller en les agitant deux trois fois, attention cela cuit quand même assez vite.
En même vous faîtes revenir des oignons émincés dans une poele assez grande, et quand ils blondissent vous montez une sauce avec un peu de farine et, soit un peu de bouillon (oui végétal) soit un peu de lait (faut il encoe dire végétal ?), un lait au goût pas trop prononcé, plutôt riz ou soja.
Bien sûr on assaisonne, sel, [[poivre]] du [[mortier]] (et pas du moulin, le [[mortier]] c'est beaucoup mieux, comment vous n'en avez pas encore ???) et si vous aimez, un peu de [[noix de muscade]], ou mieux encore du [[macis]], qui est en fait de l'écorce de la noix de muscade.
Ajoutez les têtes de choufleur grillées à cette sauce, puis les pâtes pour les poeler, il faut toujours poeler les pâtes dans la saucer, c'est bien meilleur.
Il faut savir choisir les pâtes en fonction de ce qui les accompagne, pour cette recette j'affectionne particulierement les Mafaldines, le top étant toujours les Strozzapreti, mais c'est quasi impossible à trouver.
La levure maltée ([[nutritional yeast]]) sera sur la table pour les addicts.
Bon appétit

'''Japan''' is an island country in East [[Category:Asia|Asia]]. Japanese cuisine is based on combining staple foods, typically Japanese [[rice]] or [[noodles]], with a soup and ''okazu'' — dishes made from fish, vegetable, [[tofu]] and the like – to add flavor to the staple food. In the early modern era ingredients such as red meats or diary that had previously not been widely used in Japan were introduced. Japanese cuisine is known for its emphasis on seasonality of food, quality of ingredients and presentation. Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of regional specialties that use traditional recipes and local ingredients. Strictly vegetarian food is rare since even vegetable dishes are flavored with the ubiquitous dashi stock, usually made with katsuo (dried skipjack tuna), and are therefore pescetarian more often than carnivorous. An exception is shōjin-ryōri (精進料理), vegetarian dishes developed by Buddhist monks. However, the advertised shōjin-ryōri at public eating places may include some non-vegetarian elements. In general, [[veganism]] does not have a large following in Japan, and many people do not know its exact meaning. When ordering food in a non-vegan place one has to make sure to clearly explain what ingredients should not be used. Simply asking for vegan or strictly vegetarian food can often lead to misunderstandings. == Eating out == It is relatively easy to find vegan places in big cities, such as [[Tokyo]], [[Osaka]] or [[Kyoto]] (check each citie's page for a list of restaurants). Non-vegan restaurants (with the exception of Indian ones) usually have very poor selection of vegan dishes. It is almost imposible to find vegan food in cheap Japanese fast-food places that serve [[curry]] or [[ramen]] because curry has meat or lard in it, and ramen is made with fish stock. However, one can always try negotiating with the staff. Sometimes they take "vegan challenge" and agree to veganize some dishes. == Buying food == Most Japanese supermarkets have a variety of basic staple foods suitable for vegans, such as beans, rice, fruits, vegetables, nuts, etc. One can also find whole sections dedicated to [[tofu]], [[milk|soy milk]] and [[natto]] (fermented soy beans). At least basic ability of reading Japanese is needed in order to buy something with an ingredient list and to be sure it is vegan. There are many cases when even simple rice crackers have fish sauce or something else non-vegan in them. There is a chain of health food shops in many large cities called ''Natural House'' that sell organic products. == Things to try == '''Please double-check ingredients before buying things listed here. Some of them may have non-vegan variations.''' * If you're looking for a quick snack, try Japanese "sandwich" ''onigiri'' (a ball of rice with a filling wrapped in a sheet of wakame seaweed). It can be bought in any convenience store. There are usually two versions of ''onigiri'' that have vegan filling – with ''konbu'' (a type of seaweed, look for こんぶ or 昆布), and with ''ume'' (pickled plums, written as うめ or 梅). There are also vegan ''onigiri'' made out of rice mixed with red azuki beans (no filling and no seaweed wrapping). If you want something more peculiar, try ''natto maki'' (look for 納豆) – a type of sushi that has natto (fermented beans) as its filling. They are usually sold near ''onigiri''. * Many supermarkets and convenience stores have ice cream made out of azuki beans or frozen juices. During the summer time street vendors also sell shaved ice ''kakigori'' flavoured with syrup. Finding soy ice cream is more difficult but some supermarkets have it in green tea, chocolate or vanilla flavour. * Soy milk (''tonyu'', 豆乳) is very popular in Japan and comes in many different flavours (the most unusual ones are green tea, azuki beans, sesame seeds or sweet potato). The most popular brand is ''Kibun'' (紀文) that makes soy milk packed in convenient 200 ml tetra-paks. Onigiri-selection.jpg|A selection of ''onigiri'' in a convenience store Onigiri-konbu.jpg|''Onigiri'' with ''konbu'' filling Onigiri-ume.jpg|''Onigiri'' with ''ume'' filling (''ume'' is written as うめ) Onigiri-ume-familymart.jpg|''Onigiri'' with ''ume'' filling (''ume'' is written as 梅) Natto-maki.jpg|Sushi with natto filling (納豆) Ice-cream-azuki.jpg|A box of azuki bean ice cream Soy-milk-kibun.jpg|Kibun brand soy milk == Things to keep in mind == * Words "meat" or "fish" are often understood in Japan as big peaces of meat or fish. Therefore it is suggested to ask more specific questions, such as "do you use fish/meat stock", etc. when ordering food. * Almost all miso soup contains fish stock or other animal products. Fish stock can be substituted by mushroom or seeweed stock, and some restaurants can do that when asked. * Udon (wheat noodle) and soba (buckwheat noodle) places are ubiquitous and appear hopeful but the stock (dashi) almost always contains animal products. It is possible to request just plain noodes and add your own ginger, shoyu (soya sauce) etc. * Almost all tempura is fried in the same oil as animal products. Tempura batter may also contain egg. * Traditional Japanese sweets are largely vegan, especially those made with ''mochi'' (sticky) rice and aduki bean paste. Also included are ''warabe mochi'', made from a fern root, and ''kanten'' (a jelly made from seaweed gelatin). However, some sweets contain milt (the seminal fluid of fish) which is called ''shirako'' ir Japanese. == Useful Japanese == Japanese use Chinese characters (kanji) and their own two "kana" alphabets for writing. It can be very useful to learn at least the most common kanji that indicate non-vegan ingredients. For example, kanji for "meat" is 肉 and comes in combination with other kanji when indicating specific type of meat – 豚肉 for pork, 牛肉 for beef, etc. The tricky part is that sometimes kanji are written in kana. For example, word "katsuo" (the name of fish added to many foods) can be written as 鰹, かつお or カツオ. In general it's useful to learn katakana as it's used for transcribing foreign, mostly English, words. Once you know its 47 characters you'll understand most of the words written with them (e.g. gelatine – ゼラチン (zerachin), lard – ラード (rado), yoghurt – ヨーグルト (yoguruto), etc.) [[File:Japanese-ingredient-list.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Typical Japanese ingredient list on food packages. The list starts with word 原材料名 (''genzairyomei''). The red underlines are added to show ingredients that are definitely non vegan.]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Meaning !! Pronunciation !! ウェイ or ホエイ |- | Gelatine || zerachin || ゼラチン |- | Honey || hachimitsu || 蜂蜜（はちみつ） |} Basic phrases: * ''watashi wa veegan/bejitarian desu.'' ––– I'm vegan/vegetarian. * ''_____ o taberaremasen.'' ––– I don't eat ______. * ''kore wa veegan desu ka?'' ––– Is it vegan? * ''kore wa ____ ga haitemasu ka?'' ––– Does it include _____ (e.g. meat, milk, etc.)? * ''____ ga arimasu ka?'' ––– Do you have ______? * ''____ nuki de dekimasu ka?'' ––– Can you make it without _____? == Links == * [http://vegansociety.jp/ Vegan Society of Japan] * [http://www.happycow.net/asia/japan/ List of vegan and vegetarian restaurants in Japan on Happycow] * [http://www.vegietokyo.com/index.html Tokyo Vegetarian Guide] * [http://vegan.meetup.com/389/ Vegan Tokyo Meetup] * [http://veganjapan.info Vegan Japan Info] * [http://vege-navi.jp/ Vege-navi restaurant guide] * [http://www.vegetarian-restaurants.net/Asia-Vegetarian-Restaurants/Tokyo-Vegetarian-Restaurants.htm Tokyo on Vegetarian-Restaurants.com] == Acknowledgements == This page was prepared by using some information from [http://vegan.wikia.com/wiki/Japan vegan.wikia.com] and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_cuisine en.wikipedia.org]. {{Template:Japan}} [[Category:Japan]]

'''Tokyo''' is the capital and the biggest city of [[Japan]]. Even though [[veganism]] is not very widespread here, Tokyo has many vegan or vegan-friendly restaurants to choose from. For those who want to socialize, there is [http://www.meetup.com/vegan-389/ vegan meet-up event] held every month.
== Events ==
* [http://www.earthday-tokyo.org Earth Day Tokyo] is organized at the end of April near Yoyogi park (close to Harajuku and Shibuya stations). Many vegan restaurants and animal rights organizations have their stalls during the event. * [http://www.tokyo-vegefest.com/english.html Tokyo Vegefood Festa] is held at the end of October in the same place as Earth Day. It's a good time to meet people from vegan, vegetarian or animal rights organizations and try all kinds of vegan food.
== Eating out ==
Tokyo has around 30 100% vegan restaurants. Most of them are concentrated around Shibuya and Shinjuku stations. Keep in mind that finding places in Tokyo can be challenging because of complicated address system.
'''Around Shinjuku'''
* [http://lovinghut.jp/ Loving Hut]. Address in Japanese: 東京都新宿区四谷3-6-15 ([http://goo.gl/maps/YeI5I map]), around 2 km from Shinjuku station or 50 m from Yotsuya Sanchome metro station. Sells lunch boxes for 600yen and very tasty tofu "cheese" cakes for 400yen. * [http://www.ain-soph.jp/index.html Ain Soph], address in Japanese: 東京都新宿区新宿3-8-9 ([http://goo.gl/maps/JDVLu map])
'''Around Shibuya'''
* [http://www.vegancafe.jp/ Vegan Healing Cafe], address in Japanese: 東京都渋谷区宇田川町6-20 ([http://goo.gl/maps/jZm5o map]). Main dish + drink + dessert cost around 2000yen. * [http://hanada-rosso.net/index.html Hanada Rosso]. Address in Japanese: 東京都渋谷区神宮前6-28-5 ([http://goo.gl/maps/O9wul map]), around 1.5 km from Shibuya or 500 m from Harajuku.
'''Western Tokyo'''
* [http://www.organic-base.com/cafe/ Base Cafe], address in Japanese: 東京都武蔵野市吉祥寺南町1-6-7 ([http://goo.gl/maps/RYWVu map]), close to Kichijoji station. Serves organic food, main dish + drink + dessert cost around 1700yen.
== Links == * [http://vege-navi.jp/?tokyo_vege_map&l=2 Tokyo's map with vegan and vegetarian restaurants] * [http://www.happycow.net/asia/japan/tokyo/ Tokyo's Happycow]

This recipe uses some non-standardized (not exact) measurements and can therefore be adapted to most kitchens that do not have measuring cups or scales. For "one cup" choose a medium-sized drinking vessel, larger than the average [[Turkey|Turkish]]-style tea glass but smaller than a pint glass. Use this one glass to measure anything requiring a cup, and the proportions will be fine. For "teaspoon" and "tablespoon", you can actually add to your taste. A "teaspoon" is generally a smaller-sized dessert spoon, whereas a "tablespoon" is considered larger (perhaps by double).
== Ingredients == * 2 cups flour (unbleached, any type should suffice, although wheat [[flour]] would work best) * 3/4 cup sweetener (raw cane [[sugar]] is ok, but you can try using other sweeteners like [[carob]] [[pekmez]]) * 1 teaspoon baking soda * 1 teaspoon baking powder * 1/2 teaspoon finely ground salt * 1 cup fresh orange juice * 1/3 cup vegetable oil * 1/2 teaspoon [[ginger]] powder or finely ground ginger * 2 clementines / mandarine oranges cut into small pieces * 1/2 cup dried cranberries
== Directions == * Mix all dry ingredients together in a large bowl first. * Then slowly mix in wet ingredients. * If using pekmez instead of sugar, mix that with the orange juice first. * Add clementine pieces and dried cranberries last. * Bake on medium heat in an oiled bread or cake pan for 40-45 minutes (if it is a Turkish [[baklava]] oven), or until ready.
[[Category:Recipes]]

'''Falafel''' is a [[Middle East]]ern staple food. It's excellent for [[veganism|vegans]].
== amylin's recipe == I do not use standard measurements when making falafel. I use available ingredients and measure spices and flavors to taste. I encourage you to do the same. A strong food processor or blender is highly recommended for this recipe.
[[File:Baked_falafel.jpg|400px|thumb|right|Amylin's baked falafel with rice pilav and sautéed carrots]]
'''Ingredients''' * dried chickpeas, soaked in water overnight * onion, finely chopped * garlic, minced * fresh parsley, finely chopped * dried red pepper, to taste * ground black pepper, to taste * cumin powder, to taste * salt, to taste * a few pinches of flour or bulgur to absorb moisture * a lot vegetable oil for frying
'''Directions''' * After soaking the chickpeas, some people prefer to boil them for an hour to soften them even more. This step can be eliminated if the chickpeas feel soft enough. They should not be as soft as when making hummus, though. * Drain water and blend chickpeas, onion, garlic, parsley, peppers, cumin, and salt in a food processor. * To absorb excess moisture, add enough flour or bulgur to form small balls. Set them aside on a baking sheet or plate. * While forming balls, slowly and carefully heat plenty of vegetable oil in a large steel pot on the stove. This process takes several minutes. * Using a slotted metal spoon, gently lower one falafel ball into the heated oil. The ball should start sizzling and there should be enough oil to cook it evenly on all sides. * If the oil is hot enough, you may add several falafel balls at once, stirring them gently. It should take only a few minutes to cook each one thoroughly until they are golden brown. Their color will darken once removed from the oil. * Once sufficiently cooked, remove the balls and let them sit on paper towels or newspaper to collect excess oil. Repeat the process until all balls are cooked.
Note: I prefer to use soaked chickpeas over canned chickpeas. I think the consistency comes out better. I use kırmızı pul biber as the red pepper. Ground cayenne pepper may be too spicy. I have also tried baking the falafel balls in the oven, which can also work, but you should be attentive to make sure they don't overcook.
[[Category:Food]] [[Category:Recipes]]

'''Istanbul''' is a city in [[Turkey]]. There are many [[veganism|vegan]] alternatives around, from specific restaurants to street [[food]].
== Street Food == ''Etsiz çiğ köfte'' - traditionally made with raw meat, it became illegal to sell that version (although if you are offered homemade ''çiğ köfte'' it is likely meat, so ask). Luckily they decided to make it vegan-friendly! It contains [[bulgur]], tomato paste, red pepper paste, spices, chopped onions, green onions, fresh mint, parsley, pomegranate syrup and lemon. It is eaten as a ''dürüm'' with bread (3TL), or you can buy a portion with just the ingredients for about 6 to 10TL.
''Mercimek çorbası'' and ''ezogelin çorbası'' (lentil soup) - available in lokantas and restaurants everywhere, normally for between 1 and 3 lira. Occasionally made with fat however, so ask if you can! Comes with free bread always.
''Fasulyeli Pilav'' (beans and rice) - occasionally cooked with chicken or beef broth, so definitely ask! Costs around 3TL, very filling. Also available in kiosks, restaurants and lokantas.
== Restaurants == * [http://govindaistanbul.com ''Govinda Restaurant''] - Indian vegetarian restaurant in Beyoğlu with plenty of vegan options, mains typically less than 10TL. Not bad food, but there are better places that other people can add. * ''Felafel House'' - just off Taksim square, walk down the street next to Simit Sarayı, perpendicular to Cümhuriyet Cadessi, about 100m down. ''Dürüm'' for 6TL, highly recommended. * <small>''add more?''</small>
== Useful Turkish == * ''Etsiz mi bu?'' ––– Is this without meat?
* ''Et yada tavuk suyu var mı içinde'' ––– Does this have meat or chicken stock?
* Substitute ''Et yada tavuk'' (meat or chicken, see phrase above) for these other words: ''balık'' - fish, ''süt'' - milk, ''yumurta'' - egg, ''peynir'' - cheese, ''tereyağı'' - butter, ''yoğurt'' - yogurt.
[[Category:Turkey]]

Rien de plus simple que de faire une bonne pâte brisée végan, qui pourra être utilisée à volonté aussi bien pour faire des pates sucrées que des quiches salées, des tartes aux légumes, des tourtes.
Ingredients 200 gr d'eau 500 gr de farine si possible complete 2 cuillères à café de sel marin (c'est toujours mieux) 6 à 8 cuillères à soupe d'huile (j'utilise habituellement de l'huile d'olive, mais fa^tes à votre gout), un peu plus selon mon expérience si on utilise un robot pour pétrir
C'est bon vous savez déjà tout, il suffit de pétrir tout cela, à la main ou au robot
On étalera au rouleau après avoir laissé reposer une heure à température ambiante.
Les quantités données permettent de garnir entre deux et trois fonds de tarte de 25 cm.
Cette pâte peut etre congelée, mais si vous la congelez en boule il faudra la laisser décongeler 24 h à l'avance pour réussir à l'etaler, et encore elle n'aura pas une élasticité parfaite.
D'habitude je congèle cette pâte mais déjà étalée sur un fond de tarte, et d'avoir ces choses toutes prêtes me dépanne bien lorsque je n'ai pas trop de temps pour cuisiner pour des invités surprise.
[[Category:Français]]

revision.text:
Pastry recipes (eng)
Recettes de pâtes (fr) [[pâte brisée]]

This article aim is to identify and study the linkages and bridges between veganism and other ways of life, thought, or philosophies.
=== Veganism and Politics ===
If we cannot reduce veganism to a particular political group, one can not deny that the vegan choice and adopting a vegan lifestyle is in itself a political act : the protection of animals, the antispécism, the ecological motivations, veganism seen as a means of regulating north-south trade, everything shows how vegans, whatever their motivations, are in the center of public life, in the center of the '''polis'''.
=== Veganism and anarchism ===
Many anarchists consider that the political struggle doesn't end with humans and choose to live a vegan lifestyle.
=== Veganism and esperanto ===
Coming soon
=== Veganism and nudism ===
<!-- I know some will raise eyebrows when they will see this paragraph, talking about the relationship between veganism on the one hand and nudism and naturism on the second hand. But these two lifestyles-->
Veganism and nudism have been linked since their origins.
In [[France]], the famous anarchist geographer [[Elysée Reclus]] is often considered one of the founders of French anarchism, veganism (he defined himselfas [[légumiste]]) but also of naturism.
Subsequently many naturist communities adopted the vegan lifestyle, and vice versa.
The justification of this linking may be as numerous as those for choosing a naturist lifestyle or a vegan one.
We can not deny that the two ways of life and thinking are based on a repositionement of the individual in his environment, reconsidering its relationship with nature, life in general, with each other, with the animals, the return to a lifestyle easier and with less artifice.
A small web community continues to brandish the flag of vegan naturism with ethics and sincerity worthy of esteem.
* http://nakedvegancooking.com/about/
Moreover, we can only emphasize the quality of their culinary preparation which just gives some people the desire to undress...
[[Category:Philosophy]]
[[Category:Europe]]

{{stub}} Although the actual term "vegan" was coined in 1944 when the history of modern and well-defined veganism starts, the roots of vegan lifestyle go many centuries back. Veganism does not come from one single culture, but has it beginnings in many different places, from Jainists in Asia to the filosophy of Leonardo da Vinci in Italy.
=== Jaînism ===
The Jaïnism, one of the main historical Indian religion, apeard around 680 BC. Its founder, Mahavira, attached great importance to life ; today the word ahimsa (the main Jain rule, religious wish) means in Hindi "non-violence".
Jainism respects life in all its forms, therefor Jains exclude from their diet all meat, fish, egg, honey, unfiltered water and plants with roots (because animals may be killed by tearing).
Some Jain ascets also wear on their face a mask of cotton so as not to swallow microscopic animals, and Jains in India have opened several hospitals for animals or even houses for animals to retire.

'''Kaunas''' is the second largest city in [[Lithuania]]. Although from a first glance Kaunas might not seem a very [[veganism|vegan]]-friendly city, it has in fact an active vegan community (as in [[Vilnius]]), as well as there are a few good places for eating out.
==Eating out== Vegetarian/vegan: * ''[http://www.facebook.com/pages/Restoranas-Ganga/124936060902405 Ganga]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=187+Paneri%C5%B3+g.,+Kaunas,+Lithuania&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.917079,23.90831&spn=0.053575,0.169086&sll=59.326142,17.982052&sspn=0.190208,0.676346&oq=kaunas+Pan%C4%97ri%C5%B3+g.187&hnear=Paneri%C5%B3+gatv%C4%97+187,+Kaunas,+Kauno+miesto+savivaldyb%C4%97+48437,+Lithuania&t=m&z=13 Panėrių 187]. Indian vegetarian cuisine. Ask for vegan options, without dairy ([[ghee]], etc.). * ''[http://www.radharane.lt/ Radharanė]'', address: [http://www.radharane.lt/mus_rasite.html Laisvės 40]. Indian vegetarian cuisine. Ask for vegan options, without dairy ([[ghee]], etc.). * ''[http://www.samosa.lt/ Samosa]'', address [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=5+E.O%C5%BEe%C5%A1kien%C4%97s,+Kaunas&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.898033,23.902473&spn=0.0134,0.042272&sll=54.898613,23.899963&sspn=0.0067,0.021136&hnear=E.+O%C5%BEe%C5%A1kien%C4%97s+gatv%C4%97+5,+Kaunas,+Kauno+Apskritis+44253,+Lithuania&t=m&z=15 E.Ožeškienės 5]. Vegetarian ayurvedic food and shop. * ''[http://arbatine.doodlekit.com/ Vilties vaistinė-arbatinė]'', address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=100+Laisv%C4%97s+al%C4%97ja,+Kaunas,+Kaunas+Region,+Lithuania&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.897712,23.905091&spn=0.0134,0.042272&sll=54.898033,23.902473&sspn=0.0134,0.042272&oq=100+Laisv,+Kaunas&hnear=Laisv%C4%97s+al%C4%97ja+100,+Kaunas,+Kauno+Apskritis+44252,+Lithuania&t=m&z=15 Laisvės 100]. It is a vegetarian café (probably oldest of its kind in Lithuania), with some vegan options. Much of what is sold there seems vegan, but one has to check for ingredients, since it is known that [[honey]], [[gelatin]] and [[casein]] and often used in their rolls, desserts, etc. Friendly staff, but does not speak English very much. * ''Žalių kokteilių baras'', address: [http://maps.google.se/maps?q=9+Vilniaus+gatv%C4%97,+Kaunas,+Kauno+Apskritis,+Lietuva&hl=sv&ie=UTF8&ll=54.896515,23.890522&spn=0.0067,0.021136&sll=54.897719,23.905088&sspn=0.0067,0.021136&oq=Vilniaus+9,+Kaunas,+Lietuva&t=h&hnear=Vilniaus+gatv%C4%97+9,+Kaunas,+Kauno+Apskritis+44281,+Litauen&z=16 Vilniaus 9]. Raw cocktails.
Veg-friendly: * ''[http://www.facebook.com/CafeMoksha Moksha]'', address: Vasario 16-osios 6. Indian/Thai cuisine. Vegan and vegetarian meals are marked separately. Food 9,7/10, service 10/10, vegan friendliness 9/10 (according to a vegan review [http://kavalgoveganai.blogspot.se/2013/02/moksha.html here]). * ''[http://ganbeicity.lt/ Gan Bei City]'', Karaliaus Mindaugo 49, in ''Akropolis'' shopping mall. A lot of vegetarian options from Indian, Thai, Chinese, Japanese cuisine. Some of them are vegan.
{{Template:Lithuania}}
[[Category:Lithuania]]

'''Klaipėda''' is the third largest city in [[Lithuania]]. It is hardly the most [[veganism|vegan]]-friendly city, although it is known that some of the folks there are followers of [[raw food]] movement.
==Eating out== There are no known vegetarian or vegan restaurants in Klaipėda except for ''[http://www.facebook.com/pages/Ekologi%C5%A1k%C5%B3-preki%C5%B3-krautuv%C4%97l%C4%97/196258117053889 Sula]'' (address: [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=ma%C5%BEvydo+al%C4%97ja+6+Klaip%C4%97da&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=55.712958,21.13055&spn=0.006564,0.021136&sll=59.326142,17.982052&sspn=0.190208,0.676346&hq=ma%C5%BEvydo+al%C4%97ja+6+Klaip%C4%97da&radius=15000&t=m&z=16 Mažvydo 6]) which is more of an eco-shop with a possibility to get freshly pressed juices and some limited choices of vegetarian food. How much vegan it is is a question.
{{Template:Lithuania}}
[[Category:Lithuania]]

'''Šiauliai''' is a city in [[Lithuania]].
==Eating out== There are no known vegetarian or vegan restaurants in Šiauliai except for ''[http://www.meniu.lt/valerijono-sveiko-maisto-arbatine Valerijono (sveiko maisto arbatinė)]'', situated on [http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Vilniaus+173+%C5%A0iauliai&sll=54.895987,23.906044&sspn=0.022458,0.055189&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=173+Vilniaus+gatv%C4%97,+%C5%A0iauliai,+Siauliai+Region+76001,+Lithuania&ll=55.933187,23.311961&spn=0.021876,0.055189&z=14 Vilniaus 173].

'''Panevėžys''' is a city in [[Lithuania]].
==Eating out== There are no known vegetarian or vegan restaurants in Panevėžys except for a vegetarian ayurvedic café and shop ''[http://lt-lt.facebook.com/pages/RASAJANA/219906841361910 Rasajana]'' on [http://maps.google.se/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=sv&geocode=&q=Savanori%C5%B3+a.+12+Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys&aq=&sll=54.897723,23.905088&sspn=0.006416,0.021136&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=12+Savanori%C5%B3+aik%C5%A1te,+Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys,+Panev%C4%97%C5%BEio+apskritis+35001,+Litauen&t=h&z=16 Savanorių 12].
{{Template:Lithuania}}
[[Category:Lithuania]]

'''Šakiai''' is a small town in [[Lithuania]].
==Eating out== In ''IKI'' shopping mall on [http://maps.google.com/maps?q=Ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios+gatv%C4%97+16,+%C5%A0akiai,+Marijampol%C4%97s+apskritis+71001,+Lithuania&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=54.953125,23.045883&spn=0.026763,0.084543&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=37.735377,86.572266&oq=Ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios+16,+%C5%A0akiai&geocode=FUePRgMdAYlfAQ&hnear=Ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios+gatv%C4%97+16,+%C5%A0akiai,+Marijampol%C4%97s+apskritis+71001,+Lithuania&t=m&z=14 Bažnyčios 16] you will find a vegetarian ayurvedic café ''[http://www.facebook.com/pages/PURI-ajurvedin%C4%97-virtuv%C4%97/268492099928666 PURI ajurvedinė virtuvė]''. If you want [[veganism|vegan]] options, you will most likely be in need to explain that you want no dairy (ghee, etc.) in your food. It is advised to have a Lithuanian guide since very few speak English in such small towns as Šakiai.
{{Template:Lithuania}}
[[Category:Lithuania]]

[[File:Köttskatt nu.JPG|thumb|300px|A Swedish banner, used for campaigning for carbon tax on meat, says "Stop climate chaos / Meat tax now / Meat is worse than cars, 18% vs. 13,5% of greenhouse gases".]] '''Sweden''' is a country in Scandinavia, Northern [[Category:Europe|Europe]]. It is fairly easy to be a [[veganism|vegan]] in most of the bigger cities, especially in [[Stockholm]], [[Gotenburg]], [[Malmö]] and [[Umeå]].
Veganism in Sweden had its boom in early 1990s mostly because of [[Animal Liberation Front]] attacks, when the term "militant vegan" became well-known. Since then, though, veganism was mostly associated with healthy eating, political animal rights campaigns and such.
==Activism== There are quite a few organizations which promote veganism in one way or another.
* ''Djurens Rätt'' is the biggest [[animal rights]] organization in Scandinavia, with around 32'000 members. Website: http://www.djurensratt.se * ''Djurrättsalliansen'' is another big animal rights organization which is often more radical than ''Djurens Rätt''. Webiste: http://www.djurrattsalliansen.se * ''Svensk mat- och miljöinformation'' is a NGO which focuses on food's impact on environment, and promotes veganism from environmental concerns. Mostly known for its long campaigning for carbon tax on meat (a motion on that was once already discussed in Swedish Parliament). Website: http://smmi.nu * ''Veganföreningen i Sverige'' (Vegan Society Sweden), website: http://www.vegan.se * <small>add more?</small>
==Famous vegans== * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%A5rten_Andersson Mårten Andersson] is the bass guitarist for the hard rock and heavy metal groups like ''Lizzy Borden''. * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jens_Holm Jens Holm] - although recently he is more of a vegetarian than vegan, this Swedish politician, a member of Swedish Parliament, and a former Member of the European Parliament, was vegan for 14 years, actively promoting vegetarian and vegan diets and raising questions about livestock industry's ecological and economical sustainability. * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dennis_Lyxz%C3%A9n Dennis Lyxzén] is a musician best known as the lead vocalist for Swedish hardcore punk band ''Refused''. * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promoe Promoe] is a Swedish rapper, and member of Swedish hip hop group ''Looptroop Rockers''. He is known to actively promote veganism in his lyrics. * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Sunde Peter Sunde] is a computer expert, best known for being a co-founder and ex-spokesperson of The Pirate Bay, a BitTorrent search engine.
==Links== * [http://veganlife.se Vegan Life] is a Swedish online shop for vegan products (from food stuff to body care products). * [http://veganmage.se Veganmage.se] is a vegan recipe and restaurant review blog with fantastic pictures. * [http://vegankocken.wordpress.com/ Vegankockens blogg] - vegan recipes. * [http://veganforaldrar.wordpress.com Veganföräldrar] - a blog for vegan parents (especially for those in Umeå). * [http://santoshasveganblogg.blogspot.se Santoshas veganblogg] is another vegan recipe blog.
{{Template:Sweden}} [[Category:Sweden]] [[Category:Europe]]

'''Umeå''' is a university town in northern [[Sweden]].
==History== In the 1990s it became a centre of Swedish [[veganism|vegan]] culture when many hardcore punk straight edge groups picked up this ideology and promoted it in their lyrics. At the same time the term "militant vegan" was coined in Swedish media after a phenomenon when Swedish [[Animal Liberation Front]] activists started to release minks from fur farms, damage properties of companies which raised or experimented with animals, etc. Some vegan activists where jailed afterwards.
A 1996 study of over 67,000 Swedish students between the ages of 16 and 20 found that there is a particularly high concentration of [[veganism|vegans]] in Umeå. 3.3% of the students in Umeå were vegan, three to four times as many as are found in other cities in Sweden <small>(ref.1,2)</small>.
==Links== * [http://www.facebook.com/pages/Vegan-i-Ume%C3%A5/389937380820 Vegan i Umeå] is a Facebook page uniting vegans in Umeå. * [http://umeavegan.wordpress.com Din guide till veganmat i Umeå] is a vegan food blog where reviews on restaurants in Umeå can be found.
==References== <small> '''1.''' Larsson, Christel (2001). Young vegetarians and omnivores. Dietary habits and other health-related aspects. Umeå, Sweden: Umeå University. p. 40. ISBN 91-7191-983-X.
'''2.''' Larsson, Christel; Klock K, Nordrehaug Åstrøm A, Haugejorden O, Johansson G (October 2001). "Food habits of young Swedish and Norwegian vegetarians and omnivores.". Public Health Nutrition 4 (5): 1005–14. PMID 11784414. </small>
{{Template:Sweden}}
[[Category: Sweden]]

revision.text:
{{stub}} '''Dresden''' is a city in [[Germany]].
==Eating out== *''[http://www.durum-kebab-haus.de Dürüm Kebap Haus]'' on [http://plus.google.com/108786207518547701438/about?hl=en Rothenburger Straße 41] is not a vegetarian place, but is has probably one of the best falafels (in a roll) in Europe. Although the garlic (white) sauce made with dairy is originally added to the falafel, it is enough to say to them "vegan falafel", and they will make it without the white sauce. * <small>add more?</small>
==Links== * [http://www.facebook.com/pages/Vegan-in-Dresden/122533364482513 Vegan in Dresden] is a Facebook page uniting vegans in Dresden. * http://dresden.vebu.de/vegan-in-dresden - review of vegan-friendly places in Dresden ''(in German)''
{{Template:Germany}} [[Category:Germany]]
